education.title: Planning for Retirement
education.content1: The key to a comfortable retirement is starting early. Thanks to compound interest, money saved in your 20s can grow significantly more than money saved in your 40s.
education.content2: A common rule is to aim for 70-80% of your pre-retirement income. Consider Social Security, pensions, and personal savings in your planning.

tip1.title: Start Now
tip1.description: Every year you wait costs you significantly in compound growth.

tip2.title: Maximize 401(k) Match
tip2.description: Free money from your employer - don't leave it on the table.

tip3.title: Diversify Investments
tip3.description: Spread risk across different asset types.

tip4.title: Account for Healthcare
tip4.description: Medical costs often increase in retirement.

faq.question: How much do I need for retirement?
faq.answer: A common rule is 25x your annual expenses. If you spend $50,000/year, aim for $1.25 million. This follows the 4% withdrawal rule.

faq.question: What return should I expect?
faq.answer: Historically, a diversified portfolio returns 6-8% annually after inflation. Be conservative in your estimates.

faq.question: When should I start saving?
faq.answer: Now! Starting at 25 vs 35 can mean hundreds of thousands more by retirement due to compound growth.
